description:
Great food. Great authentic Chinatown experience.  Experience included a loud drunk Chinese dude talking at his table like he was at a football match. Chinatown experience also included a large family who only spoke French.

The food was Chinatown also. Huge hot and spicy shrimp. Yummmmm.  But I started with a hot and sour soup which is very good it also a very generous serving. you know you're at a real deal Chinese restaurant where they have chopsticks on the table and no Fork. But my feelings were hurt when they brought me a fork. But for those who care, I left the table with the fork unused.  But I used like six napkins cleaning my hands after peeling the shrimp.  Did I mention the spicy garlic shrimp was really good.
author: Todd C.

description:
What a shame and disrespect to Hunan Cuisine! The food is not authentic in every aspect. It's Chinese for sure, but it's never Hunan. Not everything in chili oil is Hunan or Szechuan. Damn, what people in SF are paying for?!!! You deserve better! Henry's Hunan is okay. This one I'll give F-. Good luck!  

First picture is the dish in their menu and what's it suppose to look like. The second picture is what you get on the table. 

I don't want to start "what you order online" VS. " what you get" meme!
author: Myron L.

description: Our parents' favorite restaurant in Chinatown and we dine here for most of our family gatherings. Tonight we reserved one of the rooms in second floor, the food was served to when we got there; the chicken with ginseng soup was so good that I had three bowls, the appetizers was delicious and all other dishes were great! So Yummy!!!
author: Winnie T.

description:
Well, I came by after walking around in Chinatown. Tuned up my nose and let my nose lead me to this gem!

The servers was friendly enough and they weren't hurry to rush you off versus other Chinese restaurant in its proximately, which I was pleasantly surprised by the time I came by three years ago. Lots have changed. 

The food here is amazing delicious! At least, its pretty closed to the authenticate as possible. I would not have to fly 15 hours just to tasted this delightful dishes in San Francisco!

This is a popular spot as well, the moment I sit down. It has only few table opened. I got there before the wait-lines started to formed. You know you hit the good spots when the tables continued to filled!
author: Jane C.

description:
This was the greatest experience! The food was great and the service was phenomenal.  They were friendly, quick in helping us, gave great recommendations and helped create a wonderful atmosphere.  I am thrilled this is where we ended up eating and we will definitely return on our next trip to SF!  
Foods we highly recommend: Honey Walnut Shrimp, Pot Stickers, Xiao Long Bao
author: Sheila D.

description: My friend and I LOVED the food here! We both agreed that it was oirbabky the best Chinese food we've had in our lives wow just wow. I had the chongqing chicken, which was fried and spicy, and my friend had the fresh pepper chicken which was grilled and spicy. Loved both of them! I don't know how I'll ever go back to having regular Chinese food after experiencing this place
author: Sharma S.

description:
Solid Chinese restaurant. Very approachable to non-Chinese customers with a giant menu. Orange peel chicken sauce is much too goopy. Vegetable chow mein and hunan beef were yummy. Restaurant needs a little bit of refreshing- looks old and the leather chairs in the booths ripping. 
Crowded at 3pm on a Saturday with families with young children.
author: Julia M.

description:
Dined here with my sister as I was craving for some authentic Chinese food on a whim, so, we decided to stop by Chinatown on a Wednesday #humpday. Our finals just finished and we poked our heads into some bars... we had some drinks from Vesuvio, Comstock Saloon, Li Po Cocktail lounge, the Hancock room, and whatever else we went to... but then we got hungry after and so we went here at Hunan House. Needless to say, we came here hungry and slightly drunk.

It was our first time to try out this place. The setting seemed rather intimate: dimly lit interiors, functional tables that can warm up your soups, not too crowded--just a few bunch of friends or families gathered on their own roundtables. 

They have pretty much their entire menu plastered on their glass wall, which you can see from the outside so that you can decide whether this place is something that interests you, even before you decide on going inside. In my case, I knew from the start that they have some dishes I really like because the pictures outside caught my attention. (LOL)

We ordered few dishes and all of them were pretty good. What really stood out to me were the OYSTERS. (Omg. Must have.) Get their baked oysters, it was pretty good. We also had their Hunan chicken, which was served with a ginger oil. It tasted nice and decent. I asked for "mild" spicy, but it was really spicy for me so apparently their mild is my medium hot. We ordered other dishes but they didn't stand out as much as these two.

My sis and I were having our girl-talks and those conversations usually go pretty long. I realized that the waitstaff didn't rush us at all. They were nice enough to ask if we wanted them to take pictures of us because my sis and I were taking a bunch of selfies of ourselves. 

Request for fortune cookies after your meal if they didn't automatically give you some. It was an a-OK dining experience!
author: Trish P.

description: I was torn between a 2 and a 3 here. Admittedly, i didn't have the hot pot which looks like this places speciality. I had the vermicelli with spicy pork and it was just ok. Won't be making a second visit. With so much on offer in Chinatown, I think you can find a tastier meal in close proximity.
author: Martha N.

description: Hot pot dishes are soooo good and incredibly inexpensive , especially for a group. I love Hunan House potstickers too! It cost us $39 for a giant, delicious meal for 4 including beverages and appetizers. There were all kinds of Chinese herbs in the non spicy broth and piles of fresh peppers in the spicy broth of the hot pot, so try both kinds, or mix them! If you want to impress your friends but stay on a budget, bring them here.
author: Adrienne E.

description:
We first came across the Hunan House when we were playing tourist in our own backyard. We were hungry and their menu on their window lured us in. The restaurant itself isn't much to look - dark interior, a bit outdated, be prepared to be ignored but don't be quick to judge a book by it's cover the food is so freaking scrumptilioucious! It's that damn good a new word had to be created. We were a group of 6 the first time I came and decided to order the from the family stye menu  -the hunan option and oh-my-geee it was filling and filed with all kinds of delicious options from spicy magnolia beef, to warm soothing egg-drop soup. It so darn good and fresh we have made it our "un"offical go to spot when we are in Chinatown!

I'm certain there are better restaurants with a more welcoming and attentive staff but the food is as good as it gets with a price tag that one can not resist. 

We've come back multiple times and the service is a hit or miss, but to be honest I must be some kind of masochist because at this location I prefer my meal with a side of Chinese royal treatment! The food hits the spot every time and the menu is perfect for all kinds of palates.
author: Nubia B.

description: Very surprised to find this place. If it wasn't for my friend I would never have sought out this place. I work in the FiDi and it's good for us to go out of our comfort zone to try new things during lunchtime. We decided to go to Chinatown and my friend happened to go to this place in the past. To my surprise, the food was very good. They give free ice tea or hot tea (it taste like Thai ice tea but hot), and tofu soup. The tofu soup is not that good. But the entree was very good. They provided quite a few selections of spicy and non-spicy food. The portion is really big. The service is quick but I guess due to the reasonable price of their lunch menu, it can get crowded. So I would come before 12 PM.
author: Kathy T.

description: I will have to rate this place a 1, the service was not what I expected. We had to wave down a waitress for us to order our food, and then we had to remind them about our drinks. When our food arrived we had to wait for the rice before we can start to eat. Each time we ask for something, if it was not my job to do, we had to wait each time we ask for things.
author: Jimmy Y.

description:
If you don't mind braving some thoroughly indifferent waitstaff and aggressively flagging them down for checks, this restaurant has some of the best spicy Chinese food in Chinatown. The prices are also aggressively reasonable too.

Things I've had before:

Mapo Tofu (5/5) - my favorite standby for lunch here. $8 for a big tray of savory, garlicky, numbing spice tofu? Yes please.

Guilin Rice Noodles (4/5) - generously portioned and super solid as well, though a little blander tasting (which is what Guilin noodles are supposed to be like). I'd say on par with what's offered in the perpetually popular Chong Qing Xiao Mian down the street.

Spicy Numbing Oil on wanton/chicken/beef trip/beef/fish/etc (4/5) - I'd say they all taste similar, and they are all worth your order.

Kung Pao Chicken (4/5) - even a boring classic like this is generously portioned and extra flavorful here.

As I said, the setting is a little limpid and humid and dim, and the waitstaff is a little lazy. Overall it feels like a Chinese restaurant set in a Louisiana swamp. But besides the spooky geriatric vibes, the food is great.
author: Ken H.

description: A decent Chinese restaurant in Chinatown for sure. Since it's family style, we ordered a lot of dishes to share with our group of four. The menu is slightly overwhelming with a ton of options. We started with the wonton soup, then got the garlic bok choy, chicken fried rice, salt and pepper chicken wings, and an order of tea for the table. The wings were really good - probably my favorite thing we ordered.
author: Morgan S.

description:
Service is bad plus this place is really dirty. Food wasn't good.
I wouldn't recommend this place to anybody.
author: Tatiana E.

description:
Food is okay. Not the best of the best. 
Braised pork- ordered spicy. still came out to be pretty much sweet. 

Had some stir fry calamari/squid looking things. Tasted like it was drowned in salt and msg. Made me so thirsty after the first bite. They should also put less star anise next time Bc that's mostly the flavors I could taste. 

All in all, I like their idea of hot tea. Waitresses very rude. 

Never coming back here again Bc there's more options for me in Chinatown. 

Also, don't expect your customers to tip you!!!! If they like the service, they will tip!!!!!
author: Jolene X.

description:
Decent Chinese in Chinatown. Was visiting San Francisco on a girls trip and we desperately needed a sit-down restaurant during our walking in Chinatown. 

The restaurant is clean and we were immediately seated. We ordered the wonton soup, sesame chicken, and dumplings. The food was good! But not "blow your mind" amazing. I will say we were a little disappointed with wait staff service- we had to constantly flag down a waitress for refill drinks and our check. But I guess was nice to sit for a long time to rest our legs.
author: Alexis H.

description: open untill 11?! thats total BS. maybe they didnt like mexicans in the restaurant but they sure let in some chinese family after we were told to leave because they were "closed" i guess the whole discrimination act doesnt apply to chinese food restaurants. Very embarrassing for an unpleasant lady kicking me and my children out to the curve...avoid this place at all cost
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
We decided to try this place for a late lunch.
Staff was extremely friendly and service was
above average. Presentation of the food was authentic however the taste was nothing special.
The scallops weren't cleaned and the whole crab had the insides cooked with the crab....
I don't know about others but I have eaten a lot of Chinese food and it is usually cleaned prior to cooking and serving no way were eating...
Then I had to go downstairs to the restroom and passed the tanks of crabs and the kitchen there are no words to describe how dirty 
and disguising.....Beware!
author: Sandi G.

description:
Im sorry...i just cant give higher rating. Service was horrible. Food mediocre. We had been walking and sight seeing China town and had worked up an appetite...
We walked in and were greeted by a gentleman...he was welcoming, said a party of 10 was no problem. It was about 8:30pm...sign said they closed at 10pm...plenty of time we thought...not so!
We were rushed to order quite rudely. "You order now" i just ordered what we usually do at home...no chance to try new dishes.  Our food was ok...nothing spectacular. Sweet n sour pork was cold, our won ton soup was bland. I asked for lemons.."no have" had to keep asking for water and tea refills. About 15 min after our food was brougt (maybe 9pm)  my son wanted some dumplings...waitress said No and walked away...i repeated "No"?? And gentlemen who was sitting behind us said...kitchen closed...
We had to wait for take out boxes
We had to wait for drink refills 
We had to wait for check....then we notice 20% service charge...for you know what service. Save yourself a hassle and try someplace else.
author: Judi B.

description: I don't wanna give any stars to this restaurant at all. I bought it to go noodles. This place is disgusting I found an insect inside my noodles and I've been eating half of it. If you have never eat an insect I suggest you to go to this place. You can have more than one insect to try
author: Irene S.

description:
Definitely a good place for Hunan food.
I am originally from China and know exactly how Hunan food taste like, I am glad that this restaurant make some changes(think they make the food not too spicy so that everybody can eat, but still keep the authentic Hunan flavor which is very good)
I went to this place several times and every time I feel like I am the happiest person in the world when I go there.
Also i want to mentioned a Waiter, he is a gentleman probably in his 50-60's, and I love him!
He is so polite and nice.
author: Emily H.

description:
We gave this place a shot after trying Hunan House to see how it compared. The options here seem to target Chinese people more (less more exotic options). The service was alright and the restaurant looked okay but the food was very disappointed.

Hot and sour soup - Way way too sour and not that spicy either. Tasted mostly like vinegar and nothing else. (1/5)

Mapo tofu - Very different from most mapo tofus I've had. The sauce was more of a sour chilli paste than a bean flavor sauce. Not really to my liking. (2/5)

Toothpick lamb - Bite sized pieces of spicy cumin lamb. Lamb was average in terms of juiciness. This dish was also unexpectedly very sour but it worked alright here. (3/5)

Green beans and ground pork - They make this pretty good here. Everythjng is nicely cooked and not too oily. (3.5/5)

Hunan chicken - Cold poached chicken served with a ginger oil. Well cooked and not too dry. (4/5)
author: Austin L.

description:
Food is ok at best. I came here during lunch today and ordered their lunch special which is a variety of plates you can choose from like orange chicken, kungpao chicken, mapo tofu with rice and soup included for an advertised $7.75 per plate. It's a pretty good deal considering how much food you get but the food is practically inedible. I ordered the chongqing chili chicken lunch special which came with the most bitter soup I have ever tried. The chicken came with all of these small bones intact so I had to sieve through each piece to get anything edible out of it, let alone that the chicken was so oversalted it was pretty much unsalvageable. When it came time for the check, I'd been charged $8.75 for my chicken instead of the advertised $7.75. It's not a huge deal for an extra dollar but if you're going to advertise $7.75, then you should stick to it? 

Sorry to say that I won't be coming back here. Considering your other options in Chinatown, you'd best be going somewhere else.
author: Christine W.

description: This is my favorite Hunan restaurant in Chinatown If you want to eat the most authentic Hunan cuisine here is the best
author: Jacky M.

description: Was really good. Never been there. Went there base off of the reviews. Turned out to be good. A little over price for the size of portion they give you. The sweet and sour rib bites I wouldn't gets all but two where just the dad from the meat. Other then that a nice friendly place.
author: Matthew B.

description: Amazing lunch special - soup, tea, and food for $7.25. I enjoyed my beef and broccoli with spicy sauce on the side. Surly service.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I find myself agreeing with many of the two star reviews, so here is the short of it:
  - Food is bland and over priced
  - Service is mediocre
  - Decor is standard.

We tried a variety of dishes, many of which were simply unpalatable for me. My son was excited to get the Oyster Pancake (as we had just returned from China a few months ago and he LOVED the street pancakes) only to be incredibly disappointed in what tasted like an over cooked omelette with over-sized, overly chewy bits of oyster here and there. I was able to stomach the pepper short-rib, but what we were served was mostly veggies and bone. The pot-stickers were fine, but I would have liked a fresh over frozen taste. The garlic chicken skin was alright but then again, there was barely any meat. I filled up on steamed rice and got a snack about 20 minutes later. The only reason for the second star? They validate parking if you ask them. 

If you are in the area, overwhelmed by the Chinese food options and having a hard time deciding, I recommend you try something else.
author: Dale S.

description: We entered the restaurant and were promptly seated near the front door. It did seem like they forgot we were there because it tookm a little longer to order. Our dishes came quickly after we ordered though. The lunch specials were mediocre. I ordered sesame chicken and my daughter order shrimp walnut. The shrimp walnut was deep fried and slathered with tartar sauce. It was not very tasty and I believed the tartar sauce did not add to the dish. The sesame chicken was slighly better tasting. But the chicken was chewy and dry. Maybe next time we will stick to the fried rice dishes and not the lunch specials
author: Maria M.

description: Very good. Wonton noodle soup, cucumber salad and raw potato salad were all delicious.
author: Peita D.

description:
This place is amazing. My family and I visited Chinatown for the first time and randomly happened upon Hunan House.

Service was so-so but the food was top notch. We ordered Szechuan Eggplant, Mao's Braised Pork, Walnut Prawns, and Combination Fried Rice, all of which were incredibly tasty. At almost every bite, someone in my family exclaimed, "this is so good!" to the point that my mom told me to write a good review for this place. Definitely worth a try and the 5 stars.
author: Kathlyn C.

description: Great eating here! The food is authentic. It's helpful that the menu is loaded with pictures. Toothpick lamb was outstanding! The spice blend on it was delicious. The dim sum was labeled shanghai dumplings and they were 5 stars for sure. The Mongolian beef is spicy, just warm spicy, here which I love, most American Chinese makes it with a sweet brown sauces and this is my favorite way here. Service is SLOW! Keep in mind, culturally we are not all in a rush to eat and get out. It's a social/family time. If you are in a hurry, move on, you'll get frustrated and it will take away from the goodness and quality of food you are getting here.
author: Lindsey G.

description:
Hunan food doesn't get better than this. I ate their egg yolk batter green beans like popcorn - ten of them were gone in a matter of seconds. The chicken palm gives that nice, satisfying crunch. The pork knuckle isn't that great, so go for the fish with peppers or something more classic. 

Most of the complaints on this place are about the service, but it's a Chinese restaurant. Chinese places aren't exactly renowned for their service because they understand that most people go for the food quality, not the service. While we were sitting there, we could hear the painful strains of bad karaoke drifting in from the place up above. 

If you want some crispy chicken, spicy beef, and hella red chili peppers, you will get exactly what you're looking for here. If you're looking for service, try somewhere outside of Chinatown.
author: Sophie W.

description:
Remember: for good Chinese food, don't go to SF Chinatown.

Went here because we were already in Chinatown and it seemed to be one of the few places with non-deplorable reviews.

We sat down, started on our appetizers (which were satisfactory). A cockroach scurried across our table..

No thanks.
author: Orun B.

description: Solid Dining choice. Not the best food in Chinatown but very good. The service makes you feel like you are part if the family.
author: J H.

description: Standard Sichuan food, price is mixed and the quality is mixed too. The service is good though.
author: Will L.

description:
TERRIBLE SERVICE

We were in San Fran for a few hours so we wandered into China Town. It was close to dinner time and we were told by a local vendor to try this place out. 

Walking up to the restaurant, I saw trashed being thrown out right outside the dirty outdoor exterior, ugh, but we went anyway... 

When we sat down our waitress was not friendly and never took our drink order.  Then she took forever to get our food order. After she took our order we never saw here again until our food came out. We still didn't even have water. 

So when she brought us our entrees she started to walk away!  I had to very matter of fact ask her to bring us drinks especially for our boys. I was done being patient. We had been walking around all day in the city, we were tired and thirsty. 

If you're semi-rude in this restaurant you get a reaction quicker.  That's not enjoyable for me.

Sorry but this is San Francisco. Foodie haven of the West Coast, there are far more better restaurants in town that would love your business and will treat you kindly. You're a guest at a restaurant not an inconvenience. So treat yourself well and go somewhere else. 

BTW-I've traveled to Beijing, Hong Kong, Seoul and Narita...and I've had friendlier service abroad than here. 

Bad service is never okay with me. I don't care if its a Chinese restaurant, McDonalds or a taco bar. 

I won't be back...ever.
author: Bunny G.

description: this restaurant deserves five stars! The food is authentic, the peking duck was our favorite. We had to order another serving. The waitress was cheeky and so hospitable. Everyone was friendly and made us feel welcome. It is a hidden gem in China Town.
author: Surya H.

description: Food was really good. A lot of options. Only thing they need to do is have better service!
author: Marc T.

description: The food at this place was less than mediocre. Service was slow and we never got the water we ordered
author: Chloe B.

description:
As far as finding a restaurant in Chinatown that is clean, this one is as close as you'll get. They actually were one of the best and cleanest we could find. The food was very delish, I ordered chicken chow mien, chicken potstickers and veggie fried rice. Pretty basic, but we weren't that hungry. It was good and not too salty or fishy like I feel some Chinese good can be. 
Service was good, the waitress let me unplug the hot pot burner to charge my phone. They don't check in with you much, but that's okay, I went from a scary 15% to 65% on my phone, sitting there practicing eating with my chopsticks. 
I'd go back next time we're in Chinatown.
author: Danielle G.

description:
Hunan House is one of my top go to spots for Szechuan food. The restaurant itself is pretty clean, good service, never a wait (unlike Z&Y) and pretty big portions. They have a pretty extensive menu and I usually just order the same few items but I've liked every single one of them. 

Appetizers:
Pancake with Beef 
Couple's Delight
Spicy Numbing Pig's Ear
Salt and Pepper Tofu

Entrees:
Deep Fried String Beans, with salty egg yolk batter (It's listed as eggplant on the menu but you can choose string beans as an alternative)
Pickled Long Bean with Minced Pork - I love this over rice
Spicy Beef Noodle Soup - a pretty big order, easily shared among at least 4 people
author: Katherine C.

description: Good service, fresh food.  Steamed dumplings are great!!! Sticky rice was good too.  Several Chinese families were eating here on a Thursday night ....a good sign.
author: Joe L.

description: Very authentic and delicious. I had delicious  duck's tongue and pork intestine. Both may seem strange but they were really great. Service is kinda slow so make sure you have time to kill.
author: John P.

description: My Experience at this restaurant was really bad. Waiters kept on complaining about the customers asking for too much and looked really pissed. I only gave this place two stars because of the mediocre food. I highly recommend eating at New Woey Loey Goey. They're featured in the SF chronicle for being the most authentic Cantonese restaurant in Chinatown.
author: Alvin L.

description: The service is very bad. The waitress is very rude and the attitude is horrible. It looks like we own them money.  The food is just ok. The yuntun noodle is not authentic. If I could give it a zero star I would. I would not recommend this restaurant at all.
author: Tingting D.

description:
This is my second time here. The first time I had hot-pot with my friend. And it was great and authentic.

Since it is the second time, we decided to go with other dishes on the menu. It is very reasonable priced and the menu is actually quite long. They carry a lot of different Chinese food there. We went there on Saturday for dinner around 5:30 PM. There was not too many people. We got our orders within 10 mins (which is really quick!).

Everything is tasty! It is hard to find a place in China town which carries great food, nice environment, not too crowded and reasonable price. We will come back when we visit China town for sure!
author: Vivian L.

description: Not sure why this place has such high reviews. We checked it out for that very reason, a large number of reviews and 4+ stars. What a major disappointment that was. First off, service sucked to be frank. They took forever to even acknowledge us after being seated. The time between ordering our appetizer and meal was at least 30 Minutes. We asked for water twice and it never came. Now for the dishes, we had three. Spicy beef with black bean, Kung pow shrimp and the crispy dungeness crab. The beef was tough and lacked flavor, the kung pow chicken had a tasty sauce but the chicken itself was questionable, and the crab was just extra greasy. The hot tea and pot stickers were actually pretty good. I wouldn't return to this establishment for the previously stated reasons. Do better.
author: Nathaniel L.

description: Went here with a party of 6 and we all had the Mandarin dinner.  SO GREAT! We had tons of food and it was all very flavorful! The family style method was very fun, soup, appetizers, and 6 entrees! The service was quick and our bill was about 20 each including tip!
author: Amelia D.

description: The customer service was really bad, the women waitress was very impolitely, and my friend heard that she said bad words to us, but we did not do anything. Food is good but the customer service is the worst!!!
author: Agnes L.

description:
I love spicy food! Just try to not have them too often!

Sometimes I realized that it's pretty hard to find a good place to eat in Chinatown, that's my honest opinion; the restaurants are overrated or have terrible services. This place is not bad. 

The size of the restaurant is not that big, about 20 tables. I went on a weekday night and it was packed with people, no wait though. The atmosphere is a little bit dark with a few spot lights on tables. 

They have the option of hotpot and/or just regular dining. I am not going to talk about how spicy it is because everyone handles spiciness differently, but I was fine with most dishes. 

Jalapenos with Preserved Eggs (5/5) $5.95- In case you didn't know, preserved eggs are preserved in a mixture of different ingredients for at least a month and they usually have a very strong taste with slight acidic aftertaste. This is a cold appetizer with house-made spicy garlic sauce. It's so good! Everything is good with garlic though. 

Chong Qing Chicken with Explosive Peppers (3/5) $7.95-Not bad overall. They used chicken wings for this dish, I don't quite like how they cut the chicken wings in small chunks, because that gives small pieces of bones from the cut. So, watch out. I think it was too salty with just a little too much MSG.

Nonetheless, most dishes are spicy, so they do put a lot of chili as well as chili oil. I suggest  not drinking cold water while eating oily food. It is always good to pair spicy foods with white rice. 

Bottom line, I would visit again.
author: Tammy C.

description:
I'm really happy about this new addition to Chinatown. The food is authentic. The decor is clean but channels old China luxury. And the waiters are sweet/bilingual!

The dishes came out just as the pictures portrayed, and the flavors / portion sizes were great. The menu can be overwhelming at first, but just sit with it for a couple of minutes, take a leap of faith, and I think you'll be pleased.

I've been here 3 times now, and would highly recommend the beef pancake and the lamb with scallions. One quirky thing to note - they charge $0.50 per take-out box.

Still a lot more dishes to try. I'll keep you posted.
author: Linda X.

description:
This place is awesome!!!.   Ordered a random motley of dishes and each one was a hit:
1) free soup - seaweed carrot and pork.  Nice clean flavor.  
2) tong choy with bean paste - flavorful and well cooked - not too oily.  Maybe too many thick ass stems but not a big deal.
3) Szechuan spicy cold noodle - amazing numbing peppery sesame paste goodness.  noodles weren't quite al dente but still yummy and better than most places.  
4) egg white tofu with mixed mushrooms - loved it, egg tofu is my fav.  Crushing it.
5) explosive chili chicken - chicken had the perfect amount of light breading, more numbing pepper and super juicy.  Had the option to choose with bones or without - an unexpected nice option.

Def check this place out.  Doesn't seem like it gets super packed but its only 2 months old.    Oooh they just mentioned free taro tapioca dessert - score!
author: Olivia T.

description:
I got confused here with Hunan Home, which seems to have way more reviews and is packed/popular... there's a lot of choices in Chinatown, but I ended up walking in here... 

You get the stereotypical royal Chinese service treatment here... as in, forgotten and left alone... lol 

Like I walk in and nobody greets or helps for several minutes... Finally get seated and no menus or anything for another several minutes... lol seriously??!?!? Yeah, we just want to sit down in the restaurant and watch instead of eat. 

I had to be generic and order Kung Pao Chicken to see what "real Chinese food" version would be like... it was just super spicy but the chicken itself was hard and flavor was not good at all... 

I guess they expect over 20% tip and not bring back change either. Well, it was definitely an "authentic" Chinese experience in Chinatown. lol
author: Kiyo M.

description: One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city. Always very fresh and good amount of spicy. Highly recommend the Spicy Numbing Beef Noodle Soup and Szechuan Eggplant
author: Alexandra T.

description:
Very kind and helpful bilingual staff, we had the sesame chicken ( pretty good, very large lunch portion ). salt and pepper tofu ( delicious- salty and crispy just how its supposed to be ). and the dunplings which came freshly steamed in a dim sum basket and were fantastic. 
Decor is cute, and the place is clean. 
I would definetly come again.
author: Alexandra F.

description:
Even though it's china town it can be surprisingly hard to find good Chinese. This is the place you're looking for. Very chill and the food is really really good. 

Had sea weed salad, spicy black fungus, and the frogs legs. Incredible flavors, especially the fungus. Please don't order lame stuff like beef with broccoli or orange chicken. It's not even Chinese food. 

Fun fact: chairman Mao was born in Hunan province.
author: Dennis O.

description:
One of the greatest 桂林米粉（Guilin rice noodle) I have ever had. It comes with many healthy ingredient - spinach, beef, beef tripe, peanut, acid beans, and even quail eggs! I had never expected all of my favorite food summoned in one bowl. Not only that the rice noodle texture is very good. I had too many SF chinatown cantonese restaurants that had never met my definition of "rice noodle". The soup is definitely comfortably mild for you stomach. Of course, this is personal taste but I highly recommend this dish. 

酸豆角炒肉 (aid bean fried ground pork) is above-averagely good as I love Chinese sauerkraut and it's not common even in Chinatown. I also recommend 毛家红烧肉(braised streaky pork) if you enjoy streaky pork like me:) but it's heavily sauced and fat intensive - be careful if you crave for healthy ones. 

火爆腰花(Saused Pig's kidney), not very good, it's overly cooked.
鱼香肉丝(Shredded pork with garlic sauce), average.

Price is fair given the quality and quantity. Environment is very good in Chinatown because it's newly opened for about just a year. Service is average.

5 star for the 桂林米粉（Guilin rice noodle), cheers!
author: Yixi F.

description:
Came in for a lunch during break, walked in with no greet, staffs there just ignored the fact that I am standing in front of them, I said "excuse me" in Chinese and they just turned around. Well then, since they are so busy, so I turned around and about to walk away. Then this lady who's in her 60-70s said hello to me and asked me how many people. She told me to wait because she will clean the table for me. Of course I waited. Then a next party came up, tourists, and this reception person immediately greeted them, and guide them to the table that lady JUST cleaned for me. I came up to that man and asked I was next in line. He said there's no table for you. I explained again that lady was preparing the table for me. He said there is no table for you now. OF COURSE! He just gave that table to another party! 

That's it! I am done with this non sense. Go ahead and treat the tourists like VIP and ignore the local customers!
author: Rebegi G.

description:
I'd like to give it 4.5 stars.

Kinda just bumped into this place several months ago.  Turned out to be really very good.  We went back tonight and the food was just as good if not better.  Consistency.

Menu is extensive and the portions are - unusually - generous.  I think this is actually one of the better Chinese places I've been to lately.

The only less than good part are the guys smoking out front.  The smoke wafts through the louvers above the main entrance so you get to share one with them whether you want one or not.  But, hey, this is Chinatown and it's all part of it.  I'm not looking for Applebee's.
author: Steve F.

description: Stunning! Fantastic! Delicious! These words don't say enough! The best Chinese food in the city and worth the wait time of 30 minutes!
author: D P.

description: This is a great place to enjoy Hunan food. Food is good and prices are reasonable. Vast choice of food, a great deal in the middle of SF Chinatown!
author: Florence G.

description: Terrvle service. Waited for 15 minutes and was completely ignored. Finally just walked out.
author: Christina Y.

description: We were from out of town and did not know where to eat. We looked up the area we were in and found this restaurant. The ratings were good so we decided to give it a try. The food was absolutely amazing!!! The presentation was beautiful and the staff was pretty great as well. I will definitely be back again.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Lacking in good Chinese on the central coast I made my way to San Francisco to experience the local flavors. Went to Hunan House in Chiba Town after reading a number of reviews. The restaurant had the local charm while having a slightly modern feel. 

The dishes were tasty and some had quite a bit of spice. I really liked the wonton soup and the mapo tofu. The mapo tofu had a super bright red color and spice to match. aye every drop from the plate. I would recommend Hunan House while in San Francisco china town.
author: Andrew B.

description: Good food, it looks clean. But terrible service. Those ladies should learn to smile more and be nice to their customers. I would come back for the food but because if their attitude I will never come back nor recommend it to anyone.
author: Reda D.

description: We stopped by after a chilly top deck bus tour of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Yelped for a place in Chinatown & settled here.  What a great choice, service was good, food came out fast.  We ordered 3 appetizers & the fried chicken basil was the winner!  One hint: when they say spicy, it is!
author: Jana B.

description:
Clean and inviting establishment in China town. 

I came here because i was really craving shanghai dumplings ($5.95) but ended up also ordering the lunch special walnut prawns which comes with rice and the house soup ($7.95 and plenty of other options available)

The soup was a very simple and lightly salted carrot, egg, and ginger soup but I thought the broth was tasty anyway. The walnut prawns were good and not over breaded like many other walnut shrimp dishes I've had in the past. Just a lovely light batter. I particularly liked the candied walnuts! Last but not least the shanghai dumplings...these were ok. They were flavorful and filled with a little bit of fatty meat and soup, although there wasn't as much soup in them as I would have liked. The skins of the dumplings were ok and better than other dumplings I've had outside of NY. 

Service was what I expected a Chinese restaurant to be minus the rude haha. Mediocre...they don't check on you often, or pretty much ever aside from ordering and paying, but that didn't bother me much. 

Overall friendly and clean with mediocre Chinese food.  I'd come by here again, but this time I'll try one of their Hunan specialties.
author: Jess K.

description: Quick service. Clean. Great food! Would recommend getting the lotus root, Chong qing chicken and dumplings!
author: Samantha D.

description:
Overpriced and tasteless.

I meant to go to Hunan Home and I accidently typed in Hunan House(!!) and was taken here. Didn't realize it till after we finished dinner... No wonder I didn't see the Peking duck (though they did have duck chin?? - where's the rest of the duck?). Was wondering why the food was not that great. So disappointing. 

Manager sweet talks white people and wealthy looking young Chinese Americans. Customer service is horrible. You literally need to grab someone to ask a question. 

Food is overpriced and not tasty. Everything tastes oily.
author: Sandy C.

description:
Came here last year and had a bitter melon and black bean sauce dish that was surprisingly delicious. 

Went back again for the same dish. It was definitely not as good. The bitter melon was not as fresh as the first time, had little flavor, was rubbery on texture, and lukewarm when served. 

Two of us also ordered ong choy with fermented bean paste. This was served hot. But is always better with chili fermented bean paste, which would have given it more flavor. 

Won ton soup was thin skinned and fresh filling but the filling was distractingly salty, compared to everything else which could have used salt to counter bland. Texture was good. 

Hunan eggplant was served hot and cooked to proper cloud texture, but salvor was too sweet. Almost like candy. Was expecting a savory dish. 

Salt and pepper prawns were the worst of the bunch. Could tell by the off-putting smell. Old. As if frozen for way too long in an old freezer and absorbed the bad smells. Taste proved no hint of salt or pepper in the batter this has was a light texture but probably fried in grease that should have been changed out. To top it off, it was way overcooked and not hot in temperature. Haven't had shrimp that bad in a very long time. It was not edible. 

Medicinal jello was fine. 

Separate orders of white rice were dry and lukewarm. Even the tea was bitter. 

Bleh. 

Maybe this place is better or more consistent with Schezuan cuisine. Maybe we had a bad cook who wasn't good with timing and didn't taste the food.

Was really looking forward to a repeat of last year's bitter melon dish and ended up disappointed in multiple ways. Not a pleasant meal. And each dish runs about $10 at a minimum. 

We did notice people eating a fresh Schezuan whole catfish dish that is $30-40. Maybe we should have ordered that instead, for a better meal and cheaper. 

Service was slow but they were nice if you could get their attention. No one ever made an effort to check in and ask how things were. Close your menu so they know you're ready to order. 

Photos of nearly everything on a menu helps. And the have a vast menu. But offering such a diversity defeats the purpose if you can't keep quality control over freshness of product. 

With so many other great options in Chinatown, we may not give this place another chance for a while. For $50-$70 I expect a hot, fresh, tasty meal. A fast food chain would have been more satiating--and we hate fast food.
author: Spire S.

description:
I always come here with my mom. It's pretty much the only restaurant in Chinatown that I'm ever excited for now. (Have been living here for past 15 years) Food is always delicious, but you need to know what you're ordering. They're best at making Hunan food, so that's usually the spicy dishes. Try not to go for the generic Chinese dishes because those are not Hunan, so not exactly their specialty. I usually go for the deep fried eggplant, chili chicken palms, and chili oil beef. All dinners come with free soup as appetizer.

The food is fast depending on how many customers there are. They don't have a gigantic team in the back all the time because it simply isn't a place that fills up everyday. Just something you should be aware of.
author: Bijun A L.

description: The food here is very good.  We come here once every couple of months for their hotpot and appetizers.  We have recommended tons of friends to try this place.  Their service has been okay for Chinatown standard.  But tonight we had a really poor experience.  The waitress who served us tonight was rather rude. She's younger, probably in her mid 20s and wears glasses.  We ordered a soup base, a couple of hotpot dishes and cooked appetizers to start.  We got 5 people and planned to order more as we go as there's limited space on the table.   Then waitress asked us why we were ordering hot pot on such a hot day and why we ordered so little.  We didn't expect good customer service from this restaurant.  We didn't expect the waitress to be rude to us either. It's kinda odd that we have to explain ourselves to a waitress.  I don't think we would recommend people to this place anymore.  But we would come back just for the food.
author: Lori C.

description: I had the kung pao chicken and my sister had the sesame chicken. Both dishes wee great!
author: Colleen M.

description:
Amazing place.
You can taste the flavors of the well seasoned wok.
I would recommend anyone while in China town to stop by this place.
author: Curtis B.

description:
This location has a lot of history.  In the '60's and '70's, it was the Universal Cafe.  In the '80's until about four or five years ago, it was King Tin, a popular lunch spot for Cantonese cuisine and as Ken K. (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=DS0Idr2XDhz5e7ZfSy0dYA) terms "roasties".  It morphed to Meng Kee, a popular SF chain known for their " 3 dishes for $20.00" special;  they were obviously a bang for bucks place; they tried doing an AYCE hot pot menu which wasn't bad, but the protein quality often reflected the price.
After a long hiatus, this restaurant opened mid-September and, fearing it would be more of the same (cheap food, cheap quality).  Walking in to grab a takeout menu, I was surprised with the remodel job they did.  The y added booths to the right and moved the cashier area to the front.  They added track lighting and the redo gives it a classier feel.
I finally tried them on a recent weekday, phoning in my order.  Noticing their $6.95 lunch specials, I picked their Mapo tofu with rice (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=nHQXOajJS6QYdgaM25H_LA).  To my surprise, the lady who took my order asked whether I wanted milk tea or lemon tea (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=v8RZGxn-xBk7651Wzyn4hw), my choice.  When I picked up my order, they also included a small container of their house soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=C6zjd8IF40fzXtltuODiXw); for $7.56?!
Enjoyed every aspect about my meal.  Iced lemon tea on a hot day?  Check.  House soup?  Check.  Mapo tofu with multi-tiered flavors?  Check.  Funniest part of the rice plate was the presentation reminded me of a Hawaiian lunch plate with the two scoops of rice.  Big props as the tofu highlighted the dish, not the rice.  Can see this as a regular in my lunch rotation!
author: Mike C.

description: My brother took me here and I thought the food was really great!  The menu is a mix of a variety of regional cuisines, including Cantonese, Szechuan, presumably Hunan, etc.  We had the szechuan chicken (slightly battered and served on top of a ton of chili peppers), the lamb chops, ma po tofu, some Chinese vegetables, and a thin rice noodle soup.  Everything was very good, and we could make reservations.
author: Vivian W.

description: 4 stars for the chicken with explosive peppers. The dish consistens of fried chicken thighs (split in half) with chilis. Its nice and crispy, not too oily, and has a good chili kick to it. I'm still working through the rest of the menu to find out what I like and they make well. In the meantime I will keep coming back for another fix of the explosive chicken.
author: James S.

description:
Fantastic Service by May. she went beyond any of our expectations to make us feel welcome.
The food awesome.
author: Phoenix M D.

description: Always ordering takeout from here when I am around. I really like the lunch specials they have here. It's pretty affordable $7-$9 depending what you get. The light eater I am is able to have 2 meals with the lunch special. They give a pretty large portion. Taste is a little above average. I don't know why I like coming here though... Maybe because I'm too lazy to go anywhere else in Chinatown... One thing I hate is their soup containers. They poked a hole for it to breathe but since it's knocking all over the place, it spills... =[
author: Benita M.

description: Great find in Chinatown. Clean restaurant, fast efficient service and very flavorful, authentic food. We opted for the gourmet dinner combo which features the best hot and sour soup I've ever had.
author: Leigh N.

description: Food was excellent but service was terrible they do not serve you. However best sweet and sour chicken ever. Thus the 1 star.
author: Big D.

description: The best Chinese food restaurant Ive been to! I'm from Chicago but the Chinese food there is not even comparable to that from this restaurant!
author: Kay X.

description: My Chinese friends took me here. We shared 6 dishes among 7 people for lunch. The food is authentic Chinese according to my friends. I thought it was great. The food tend to be spicy and I loved it. It would be best to bring your Chinese friend because I wouldn't have know how to order otherwise. Not sure about the price either.
author: Miho T.

description: Pretty much average Chinese food, which is a bit disappointing given its location in Chinatown, but perhaps it is too close to the tourist corridor. Chow mein included an oddly large amount of noodles turing it almost into lo mein. The lamb ribs were very fatty. Best bet is the pot stickers and the onion pancake.
author: Steve A.

description: Sad! Great food but waitress poor service. Customer service makes a big difference. Please talk to your waitress to make the dining more pleasant.
author: Jocelyn S.

description: Food here is pretty good but the customer service is the worst ever.  Didn't give us menus.  Didn't take our order.  Bought us the wrong drinks.  Didn't check on us during the dinner.  Wouldn't give us a highchair or booster seat to use.  Took forever to bring us our check.  Had to yell at the owner multipli times to bring us the check and a box.  Of course they just bought the check and not a box.
author: Donald H.

description: So so so good!! We got a recommendation to go here by some local Chinese guys! We had the combo chow Kwon (yummy!!), the broccoli with garlic (yummy) and the chicken with explosive peppers (holy moly)! The food was awesome!! It's a family run place so expect slow service and I one speaking English! Overall, great experience!!
author: Vicki K.

description:
Some of food was tasty but very greasy. Otherwise not a lot different from most other Chinese I had before. Garlic noodle dish was very good and stood out. 
Lacks ambience. Strong smell of cigarette smoke in the dining area. Appeared to come from an upstairs area used by workers/family. Waitress very serious and not very friendly.
author: Adel Z.

description: Excellent flavors. Very tasty food and spicy to the highest level you want. Fresh, served in an appetizing way and you can't help but want to have just one more bite.
author: David C.

description:
Loved it here! This will be my GO-TO place in SF besides Kungfu Tea.

Had their hot pot, noodles, garlic pork belly...Everythings pretty good...
Except for the steamed dumplings...

make sure you order spicy food at this hunan place, otherwise your really missing out. I saw people order friend rice, and walnut shrimp here....its just not the best place to eat those things! You gotta order dishes that come with a pound of red pepper in it.

Service is average..they are owned by people from Hong Kong so some dont even speak good chinese...
author: Fiona X.

description:
a bit over priced for what we got but it was good.

Hot and Sour Soup was decent, a 3 rice bowl portion for $8
Salt and Pepper Shrimp, about $12. Well made, good amount
Eggplant Sauteed, about $12. Decent, definitely have had better though
Red Roasted Pork, about $13. It was well made, I enjoyed it the most.
author: Phillip T.

description: Delicious choice for lunch! So many places around here but we are glad we chose Imperial Palace. The Lemon Chicken is divine! Breaded lightly with a tangy lemon sauce. Also had the Mongolian beef which was my favorite. Spicy with fresh onions and peppers. We ventured out and tried the salt and pepper prawns which were fried with the head on and they were amazing. Also had combination fried rice and combination chow mien - both which were delightful. I recommend this place for sure. Service was good and people were friendly.
author: Christina T.

description: This was my second time back at Hunan House on Washington Street. It was AMAZING! Their food will forever be the standard that I compare all other to! We had Mongolian Beef with fried rice! Perfect blend of flavored and spice!!!!
author: Kelli W.

description: Food was good but it is not set up for a large group and no one working there apparently knows English. We asked three different people for help and they would just walk away. The forth person finally said she didn't speak English and got someone else. You only get water if you beg for it because no one ever comes back once the food is delivered to the table. I get that it's Chinatown but  come on...
author: Courtney E.

description: Looks okay from the outside . But the staff are not friendly at all. I'm so  disappointed. I will not be back Z.  Had to wait like 30 'mins for my food . And taste okay
author: John W.

description: I agree with most of the 1 atar and 2 star , this place is difficult to eat with medriocre service. We are been to to many places in our life. we know about food. We traveled from south America to Honk kong, china specially. In this place you get bad faces, descrimination is giving, if you are not from here. We eat here with force. We dislike bad manners, we like to get good service and I hope the owners read this message. In our life visit we found a long hair. My apetize when away. They has to fire the waitress. This place need kind people.
author: Ace R.

description: Have been here dozens of times. The food is topnotch. I, along with my friends have never been disappointed with the food. It's just the service that bothers me.Either they  don't care or they just want the food to complement service!! They need to do something about it and with all the reviews about bad service, someone should be seriously looking into this matter.
author: N B.

description: Everything was delicious. That's the best way to describe this place. They have so many pages of stuff to choose from, that pointing blindly on the menu will still be a good choice. I ended up getting sweet and sour chicken with garlic chow mein. It was like Panda Express make everything fresh and super tasty! I also ordered some spring rolls and green onion pancake. Those spring rolls were the best I ever had. The flavor they packed was out of this world! It renewed my lost faith in a good spring roll. The green onion was just right in its crispy texture, but soft on the inside. I tried some of my friends walnut shrimp and it was delicious as well. There are so many restaurants to pick in Chinatown, but this place was by blind luck.
author: Gill S.

description:
If you look like a student, I wish you good luck. 

It's my first time to try to this restaurant. My girl friend and I were expecting a good experience so we went in and put my name on the wait list . We were so happy that We were the first one on the list. As we wait , there was two group of people coming. One group ( two persons) signed on the wait list. I remind another group of people (two persons) to sign a name on wait list. After 10 minutes, I see there were two table available. I thought we were the first group to seat in; however, the owner told me to wait 2 more minutes and brought those two group of people seat on those tables. We saw there were not any table available. I don't get how that 2 min can gives us a table . It's totally ridiculous and silly . The only reason I think the owner let those two group of people go first because we are look like student.
author: Martin L.

description: Horrible service!!! DONT COME HERE! The waitress are very rude and dirty and the manager is even worse! I asked to speak to the manager because I ordered the Garlic Lobster dish. Well folks they only served me the lobster feet and literally the head and two claws. I asked to speak to the manager to simply ask if I was suppose to get only partial lobster or a whole lobster. And he insisted that I did get a whole lobster when I CLEARLY DID NOT!! I told him I would not be having that conversation with him if I had actually gotten a whole lobster, but I didn't get the tail part to my lobster. The manager practically called me a liar about me not getting my whole lobster. The food lacked flavor too. I will definitely NOT BE  REFERRING NO ONE HERE! And to top it all off I witness a waitress wearing gloves go in to the restroom, use it and walked out instantly after flushing still wearing the same gloves she went in with. SO clearly she did NOT wash her hands after using the restroom and went back into the kitchen. They also lie about the size of their plates. The plates of food are small and are suppose to be family size.
author: Golden G.

description: I hate chines food, but I guess I've never had good chines food. This place is the real deal. Everything we had was delicious!  It's worth a trip to the city from Napa.
author: Leslie M.

description:
It seems like this place recently underwent a change in management and renovation. We went at a relatively odd time between lunch and dinner, so we had no trouble getting a table. Our server was nice and helped us with the menu. We settled on ma pu tofu (ground pork and tofu) and some lo mein. Both were outstanding. Sufficiently flavorful, somewhat spicy but not overly spicy, and delicious. The ma pu tofu was as authentic as any I have ever had, including in China. Portions were huge and more than filling. The two of us could have easily split one dish.

I know there are bajillions of other chinese places in Chinatown, but I was happy we stumbled into this one.
author: Brent W.

description:
PLACE
- Was seated right away, even though the restaurant was mostly full.

FOOD
- The dishes were quite delicious, but took a really long time.

SERVICE
- Terrible, had to call the waitress because she had forgotten about us.

PRICE
- Fair. No steal, but good enough for price, but not service.

GO BACK?
- No. It took way to long to get our food.
author: Jhon P.

description: The first time I ate here it was amazing. However the second and third was just okay. It may be that we came in too early and the chef wasn't ready yet. We always order the mapo tofu, twice cooked pork and the beef. We definitely always get the lunch specials. One thing's for sure, you get value for your money!
author: Rachel P.

description: Chinese food is outstanding. You will crave it for days. It was that good. We go every weekend.  We can not stop. Fesh, cool new Chinese dishes they make up, and the price is perfect.
author: Flim S.

description:
Came by for lunch with some coworkers, and had a great meal.  The portions were large, prices were great, and most importantly, the food was good.

The mapo tofu and mongolian beef were quite tasty.
author: Steven H.

description: Delicious, interesting, good, friendly service that offers a true china town experience.  Veggie options, quality food and nicely presented dinners!  Yum!
author: Stephanie G.

description: Delicious pot stickers! Twice cooked pork is very authentic. Lemon chicken was pretty great too. Good, friendly, fast service and the lunch-time specials are a great deal! I recommend this place very highly!
author: Y Z.

description: poor service '！ force the people to tip ！ dont come here again ！ no good ！dont come here
author: Wilson W.

description:
My family and I were desperately searching for some good Chinese food after a less than favorable experience eating Chinese food outside of Chinatown the day before.  We were a bit concerned about the balance between landing in a tourist haven and perhaps finding a Chinese restaurant that was a bit too "authentic" for our tastes (and our non-adventurous kids in tow!).  Hunan House fit the bill perfectly.  

We started with the not-so-authentic deep fried spring rolls, which my 15 year old son eats as one of his primary food groups.  There's not much you can say about spring rolls, but these were crispy on the outside, with a steamy vegetable filling, and a light sweet-sour dipping sauce that wasn't too thick.  About as good as you can get for spring rolls.  Next course was the Shanghai dumplings.  Wow!  These plump pillows of pork-filled bliss were some of the best I've had.  They were accompanied by a slightly vinegary deep purple dipping sauce which I've never had before, but it was a perfect pairing with the dumplings.  Both of our picky kids gobbled these up in short order.

Our main courses were typical Americanized Chinese food - orange chicken and ginger-scallion beef.  But they were both perfectly prepared with fresh ingredients.  The orange chicken was a light, crispy fried breast meat with not too much and not too little orange sauce - no sign of gloppy, greasy orange chicken chunks in sight!  The ginger scallion beef ingredients were fresh and well prepared - perhaps a bit bland but nothing that a bit of hot chili oil couldn't fix.

Even the side of white rice was good.  The right mix of stickiness so you could eat it with chopsticks if you wanted.

The only (minor) complaint was that the service was a bit slow - we waited 15 minutes after being seated for the waitress to come take our order, and then when we were done eating we finally gave up waiting for the waitress to come by and clear our table and give us the check.  We just went to the front cash register and paid and it wasn't a big deal, all things considered.
author: Jeff F.

description: Good food. Attractive Manu. Nice to sit around and chat with friends.  Hunan style is my style.
author: Helen Z.

description:
We tried this place yesterday and hoping to find a good Chinese restaurant in SF Chinatown. Here's what I think:
- Small portion but taste OK (nothing special but overall not bad at all!)
- Waiters are very attentive and nice. 
- The lady in the front was rude. (visited 1/14/2016 PM)
- Yes, it is an Americanized Chinese Restaurant. 
Overall, I'm not going back there. Really not worth your money and time.
author: Lovey G.

description: There isn't really a host stand so my friends and I kinda just waited by the door until we got seated. It was like as if they didn't really notice us. Then we got to our table & our waitress looked kind of annoyed the whole time. They hardly checked up on us. & we kind of felt neglected & we had waited a long time to get our check. We actually waited so long, we had to catch their attention as they walked by. The reviews made us feel confident about this place. But I kind of felt left down. Maybe it was just and off night. So I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.
author: Norma Q.

description: Very good food. Dim Sum missing from the menu. Price moderate. Service?!?! Very very very slow taking orders, not attentive, order was fast dispatched. Mixed feelings about this restaurant, I guess kitchen is great, main floor needs better management and customer service training.
author: Mel E.

description: Bad service. The waitress is really bad at serving people. Made me almost lose appetite. The food is not as good as I expected. May be the bad service affect my appetite.
author: Yvette Y.

description:
The food is Good, quick  attention. I went there on Chinesse new year and they were really gentle; cause I arrive there at 10pm and they were happy to attend my friend and I. 
We order like 3 meals and it wasn't expensive.
author: Agostina D.

description:
I'm a fan of spicy Hunan/Szechuan food so wanted to try this place out. It replaces the Washington Café restaurant next to Kam Lok, for those familiar with SF Chinatown. The interior definitely got a nice upgrade with cozy seating and lighting.

So far I've tried the Twice Cooked Pork, Kung Pao Chicken, Beef w/Pickled Peppers, and Szechuan cold noodles. All were pretty good! 

Seems the large menu has Hunan, Szechuan, and Cantonese dishes on it..I'll definitely be back to try other items since its down the street from the office. Thumbs up so far
author: Ralph S.

description: The seasame chicken is amazing and like none other.
author: Destiny B.

description: Spicy numbing beef noodles were a big success, although I finished the dish wondering if there were actually any prickly ash peppercorns used.  Regardless, I'd eat this dish again.
author: Brian C.

description:
This is by far the best restaurant I've been to in SF's Chinatown.  Most of the food I've had in Chinatown was pretty good, but nothing special.  This place I will definitely go back to.  The food was awesome and the people were friendly.  

We had the following dishes:

* Spicy Numbing Beef Noodle Soup - really good.  I'm not sure if they dumbed it down because we're white, but it wasn't that spicy, just super flavorful with a little back burn. Great balance of broth, noodles, veg & just a little meat. Way better than I expected! 

* Shanghai Dumplings - Soupy, flavorful yummy dumplings.  A classic, and they did them justice

* Lamb Ribs - Fatty, unctuous, and just a bit spicy.  Lots of garlic.  I love lamb, so I expected to be happy, but my friend is a bit more meh about lamb and she was super impressed.  I want to make these at home! 

The only draw back to the place was that it took them a really long time to take our order and get us our check.  Once they took our order, the food got to us quickly and everyone was really nice, but I wouldn't recommend this place if you're in a huge hurry.
author: Madeline B.

description: Decent food and lunch specials for $7. Terrible service - no one comes to check on you, no drinks / water refilled and had to ask for our check - this results in my low rating. Close to Chinatown main area and easy to get to if you're willing to put up with no service.
author: Curtis J.

description: Come here with my girlfriend for dinner .love their newly decorated bar the food. tasted good and the price is right .I'm sure I'll be back
author: Henry C.

description: This place is really good for lunch and dinner! Food r just awsome and defintely gonna come bk and try out their bbq cat fish and seafood. I had the couples delight ,lamb skewers, bbq oysters and the guiling rice noodle it's just the best i had before!!
author: Nicky S.

description: Spicy green peppers were chopped in chunks with the seeds in them which takes away from the beef with hot peppers (小辣椒牛肉) dish. It's an incorrect way to prepare this dish and shows how the cook tends to cut corners. SF Chinese restaurants need to step up their game. NYC Hunan restaurants are so far ahead of you guys in authenticity and flavor.
author: Amy K.

description: Ordered the braised fish with tofu lunch special and the spicy fish with exploding chili peppers. Both very flavorful and satisfying.
author: Bea L.

description: I'm giving this place two stars because my order of combo chow main came with hot noodles in the center.. And cold beef and chicken on the edges.. And I mean refrigerate cold.. WTH?..
author: Martin W.

description: 3rd time here. Consistently yummy spicy eggplant and kung pao chicken. Comfortable atmosphere and friendly service. More Asian than western customers when we arrived during the lunch hour rush = good sign :-)
author: Stephen N.

description: Service for our table of four was a bit slow, but the food was extremely flavorful and the portions were quite generous. We each got an entree and that was probably one entree too many.  Both the popular and outlandish dishes were delicious and universally enjoyed so feel free to be brave with your selections.
author: Joseph B.

description: Where to start with this restaurant. This was one of the places recommended by our hotel. When we stopped in the host seemed annoyed that we were there. He did not greet us upon entering and all but rolled his eyes. Once we were out at a table the server never asked us if we wanted a drink. We had to ask 3 times for some water. Once the food came it just got worse. The sweet and sour chicken was hands down the worst I have ever had. The chicken was cooked but was hard. The vegetables were not cooked at all. My wife requested brown rice with her meal and was given white rice. The meals do not come with rice and you are forced to purchase some. The rice was so so. The chicken in the rice was also not that good.  The "egg roll" appetizer is actually spring rolls. They are not bad but also they are 100% not egg rolls. My wife thought her meal was fine but nothing to write home about. I would recommend you stay far away from this place unless you want a bad meal. With so many places to eat in the area and places that offer a friendly atmosphere it's worth the extra steps to those establishments.
author: Paul L.

description: This restaurant is excellent! All my favorite foods, affordable priced and cozy! Ask for their specials, they can make custom plates for you!
author: Simon W.

description: Excellent authentic Chinese food: shredded garlic pork--spicy and good eats, orange peeled chicken--also very yummy, Mongolian  beef -- also spicy, but very delicious. Also ordered garlic mushrooms and combination fried rice--these were also very good.  I personally ordered wonton soup--small bowl, but was enough to share with a table of 7.   were seated at a large table with a large lazy susan... Food was eaten family style.  The only thing we ordered doubles of was the mushrooms and rice. A definite must try
author: Vanessa F.

description: It was alright. Typical poor service, not very tentative. Had a drunk man come in here and walk upstairs and it Caused a big scene, kind of dampens the mood of our dining experience. Not very professional. They'll make you tip 10% at least.
author: Sophie N.

description: The business is more mature now.  Better communication with the kitchen.  Great food as usual. I really like the private Karaoke room upstairs.  It's a nice place to enjoy authentic Chinese food and have a good time with friends in a comfortable private room.  It is a must go place every time I am in Chinatown.
author: Jansen K.

description: There are a ton of good places to get awesome food in Chinatown.  This one is pretty tasty too and they have a huge menu.  But they have one big problem though... the service is absolutely horrible.  It almost feels like they are annoyed to serve anyone who isn't a regular.  If you're a tourist, I'd probably skip this place and go somewhere that's happy you're there.
author: Chris S.

description: Terrible customer service. Try to flag down the one waitress that was serving everyone because the other two waitress were eating their lunch after we were served our food. We only wanted a refill on water and extra napkins but the waitress was ignoring our table and one other table that never got to order their lunch they only got their drinks and left after being ignore a few times. There was enough people there working but they were to busy doing other things and not serving the customers.
author: Tina Y.

description: The service was very very slow considering there were only two other tables being waited on. The food was very good though. I had the pork belly appetizer since I love pork belly. It was enough to share with the other 3 people I was with but since they don't love pork belly like me, I got to eat it all by myself and not going to lie, kind of glad I was able to! I also had the stir fried squid. Huge portions and nice and spicy how I liked!
author: Suzy B.

description: Had string bean dish, sweet and sour chicken, dumpling, pot stickers, spring rolls, mango pudding and more with the fam.  All excellent.  This is a great place to eat.  Nicely decorated interior.  The service was good and staff friendly.
author: Rob I.

description: Went on a Sunday night where all the other restaurants in the area were super crowded. We were able to be seated immediately. The food was very flavorful and tasty but almost borderline too salty. Overall the food was good but the large party next to us had children that were very rowdy. We could barely hear our own conversations. It would have been nice if the management had stepped in since there were also other tables that seemed bother by the noise.
author: Linna G.

description: This was so good and reasonably priced. Mix of locals and tourist.
author: Jeremy P.

description: Very tasty and authentic. Soups and dumplings were very good. Spicy green beans were a surprise hit. Pineapple rice was excellent. But the big winner was the sesame chicken! Incredibly tasty and genuine, exactly why we wanted to eat in Chinatown. Service was fast and friendly. Moderately priced, but a value for money.
author: Michael S.

description: Really good Szechuan food here with great, comfortable decor. Parking can be tough, but it's worth it. A rare sf treat here. The numbing spicy beef is yummy, along with the steamed egg with thousand year egg on top.
author: Chris H.

description: Maybe best hot and sour soup ever!  Had steaming pot after - was really good.  Ordered 3 meats and tofu and could only eat half of it with two of us. One meat and a couple veggies next time. Portions are huge.
author: Josh N.

description: Terrible food there！If you are looking for real Chinese food，dont ever go there. The dish is not good，and the atmosphere is not good as well.
author: Daniel L.

description: The food was good, the service was good. I like this restaurant the most is because they have VIP room that fit 8-12 people, perfect for birthday and gathering.
author: Melody S.

description: Nice atmosphere and good food! The menu is a little overwhelming but we were happy with all our choices.
author: Taylor M.

description: I had the same experience as the comment below. That  place is a student free-zone . If you look like a student or someone who won't buy or tip too much , please don't go there  They won't go by the order lists ; they will choose people to give tables to . Last time when I was there , they gave seats to the people who just arrived instead of me who waited for half and hour .
author: Abby Z.

description:
We ordered the pork wanton in chili oil for an appetizer, the pork stomach sauteed and the beef with onions.  First, the pork wanton was bought out drowning in hot chili soup and it was not chili oil at all.  It was way too spicy and didn't have the scallions or the sesame oil mixed with it.   The pork stomach sauteed was very saucy and tasty.  It was marked as spicy but really wasn't spicy at all.  It was still good.   The beef and onion and green pepper was okay, nothing to write home about.  It was good and the two guys loved the taste of the sauce.  
This was an okay restuarant.  The service leaves very little to be desired.  It took them about 30 minutes before they even came to my table to take an order and the restuarant was pretty empty.  Then when I asked or white rice, they acted like it was a crime.  It really annoys me that you have to keep asking for white rice at all these chinese restuarants or they don't give it to you and then they charge you for the rice when the plates weren't that cheap to begin with.  San Francisco is an expensive place to eat.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I stopped in here while doing a walk around Chinatown. The decor is nice. The food is great. The service? Nowhere to be found. I don't believe I have ever had such an inattentive server. I finally had to get up and go ask for my check after 10 minutes of trying to flag her down unsuccessfully.
author: Russ S.

description: Im rating this as 3 stars and A-ok is good.. maybe is just my taste.. The food is good and good portions.. people are nice.. for me it is only a one time thing.. I mean the food is good but I wont try it again.. you know what I mean.. I recommend it to try it out because people have different tastes. I am a fan of chinese food.. all im saying is that the food we ordered is only for one time thing.. I didn't feel like Im going to eat here again and again.. once is enough for me but I do recommend it to try it out.. Ciao!
author: Juan T.

description: Took 5 Hungry boys here for lunch. Great food, and good service. We will be back for sure.
author: Andrea V.

description: Food was too salty, mediocre and overpriced. Customer service was BAD. We kept waving and calling the waitress for attention who is obviously very inattentive and we were literally the only customers there. Never coming back here again.
author: Michelle N.

description: A must try for spicy-lovers! We were a bit hesitant to check out this place since the price is slightly higher when we walked by seeing the menu outside, but I am glad we did. Instead of ordering water boiled beef, one of my favorite all time, I tried Mao xue wang. Waoh! It came to us by such a Huge portion that absolutely could stuff two starving stomachs. You could see beautiful Sichuan pepper cores joyfully swimming on the surface of red chilly oil, in which you got different pig intestines and veggies. Watch out it's so spicy that even I specifically told them to make it mild, it still pumped out sweat on my whole body. (Best way to cure a cold) Yum!!
author: Nathan L.

description: Come here with group for a birthday party like the private room the have upstairs definitely will be back
author: Bill l.

description: We had wandered through shops and up and down streets of China town for hours, glancing at restaurants here and there, knowing we wanted to eat somewhere, but couldn't choose. My daughter spied the Hunan House's signage high above the street with tantalizing photos of dishes. So, we pushed through the crowds of shoppers, tourists, and street hawkers, and stepped into a cool, darkened, surprisingly quiet dining room. No waiting to be seated either. A hostess gestured toward the tables, telling us to sit anywhere. The tables were pre-set with plates, chop sticks, tea cups, and menus. Immediately, after we sitting, a fresh pot of tea was brought, though we hadn't ordered it. The menu is large, though not exhaustive, and it includes a photo for almost every offering. Some entrees included foods that might give even a fairly adventurous diner, such as myself, pause. But there was a great variety to choose from. We ordered the Dry Fried Green Beans (I've never tried a green bean dish at a Chinese restaurant that I did not love, though they all differ from one another), Mongolian Beef, and Spicy Chicken with jalapeño. My one and only complaint is that the time we waited to give our order was very long, though the restaurant was not busy. We closed our menus and kept our phones out of sight to signal the wait staff that we were ready, but it took an unusually long time to get the attention of a server. They were very courteous, and I would not hesitate to return. The meals were wonderful, and the green beans were possibly my favorite of any I've ever had. Leftovers were just as delicious cold the next day. The sauces retained their consistency, did not become gluey, and the vegetables were still tender-crisp.
author: Diane P.

description: This place was delicious! It took a while for our food to come out because they were busy (it was a Saturday) but it was well worth the wait. The portion sizes were good and the food was well prepared. Definitely will eat here again the next time we go to San Francisco!
author: Kiyo L.

description:
This place was great! Very good service, clean, beautiful decor. I had:

Hot and Sour soup: perfect blend of hot and sour, not too salty and the "small" was enough for two people. 

Chicken Pot Stickers: Classically done with a tasty pepper sauce and great flavor.

Kung pao chicken with rice: Spicy but with a lot of other great flavors too and, happily had plenty of chicken as well as vegetables--a good balance. They also gave a lot of it--again, you could share it with another person and it would be enough.
